Felix Herrmann, felix.herrmann@gatech.edu
Abstract

The global deployment of carbon capture and sequestration technology to combat climate change requires monitoring and detection of potential CO2 leakage through existing or storage-induced faults to ensure safe and long-term viability. Recent work on time-lapse seismic monitoring of CO2 storage has shown promising results in monitoring the growth of the CO2 plume from surface-recorded seismic data. However, due to the low sensitivity of seismic imaging to CO2 concentration, additional developments are required to efficiently interpret seismic images for leakage detection. This work introduces a binary classification of time-lapse seismic images to delineate CO2 plumes (leakage) using state-of-the-art deep learning models. Additionally, it localizes the leakage region of CO2 plumes by leveraging Class Activation Mapping methods.

Introduction

According to the International Energy Agency and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report (IPCC 2018), a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 is necessary to avoid a 1.5°C increase in Earth's average temperature. This can be achieved by reducing dependence on fossil fuels, using renewable energy sources, and deploying large-scale carbon reduction technologies, such as carbon capture and sequestration (CCS). CCS involves collecting, transporting, and injecting CO2 into a geologic storage reservoir for extended periods (tens of years). CCS is considered a relatively low-cost, long-term, and imminent solution. However, potential CO2 leakage from underground reservoirs due to pre-existing or pressure-induced faults poses risks (Ringrose 2020). Therefore, it is essential to de-risk CCS projects by monitoring CO2 plumes to accurately detect and predict potential leakages as early as possible.

Time-lapse seismic monitoring has been introduced as a reliable technology to monitor CO2 dynamics in the Earth's subsurface during carbon sequestration (Lumley 2001) and is already in use at existing storage sites (Arts et al. 2008; Chadwick et al. 2010; Ringrose et al. 2013; Furre et al. 2017). Sequential seismic datasets, called vintages, are collected over an area covering the storage reservoir. Each seismic dataset is inverted to obtain high-fidelity images of the subsurface over time (Arts et al. 2008; Ayeni and Biondi 2010; Yin, Louboutin, and Herrmann 2021). The evolution of the CO2 reservoir can be visualized by subtracting seismic images between different points in time. However, due to the inherently weak and noisy amplitudes of the CO2 reservoir's response in those seismic images, detecting the presence of potential irregularities, such as CO2 plumes, corresponding to leakage is a challenging problem.

To tackle this difficulty, a machine learning-based detection method is proposed, based on standard binary classification. Recent methods leveraging machine learning have been introduced for the detection of CO2 leakage based on artificial neural networks (ANN) (Li et al. 2018a) and a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks (Zhou et al. 2019). These methods rely solely on field-recorded data rather than subsurface seismic images. Practical considerations, such as repeatability, hinder their applicability to real-world cases. This work takes advantage of advanced seismic imaging techniques, such as the joint recovery model (JRM) (Oghenekohwo and Herrmann 2017a; Wason, Oghenekohwo, and Herrmann 2017; Yin, Louboutin, and Herrmann 2021), which has demonstrated higher fidelity imaging than sequential seismic imaging, allowing for easier detection of CO2 leakage.
